awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The SuperCDMS SNOLAB Experiment
awd_abstract_narration:
Observations indicate that 85% of the matter in the Universe is not made of normal atoms but must be otherwise undetected elementary "dark matter" particles that do not emit or absorb light. Remarkably, particle physics theories proposed for other reasons predict the existence of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) with just the right properties to be this dark matter. If WIMPs are the dark matter, they may be detectable when they scatter in Earth-based detectors. Direct detection of WIMP dark matter would solve a fundamental mystery in particle physics and cosmology, providing a unique window to learning about the primary matter constituents of the Universe and of physics beyond the Standard Model of particle physics. Over the past three years, the SuperCDMS collaboration has led the field in the search for low-mass dark matter.  The most recent results from CDMSlite reached an energy threshold for electron recoils as low as 56 eV. These results excluded new parameter space for the dark matter-nucleon spin-independent cross section for dark matter masses between 1.6 and 5.5 GeV/c2.  This project will focus on better understanding the response of the signal detectors in a push to make the SuperCDMS yet more sensitive.

The SuperCDMS SNOLAB experiment will have a broad impact which extends beyond the search for dark matter. The experiment's phonon-mediated detectors have applications in cosmology, astronomy and industry. This effort will contribute opportunities for training of undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. SuperCDMS will engage in education and outreach at local institutions and will coordinate outreach at SNOLAB and the Sanford Underground Research Facility (SURF) in South Dakota to increase the broader impact with a focus on secondary education. This award will support participating in SNOLAB-hosted teacher workshops, modifying and providing middle school dark matter education modules to U.S. educators, and maintaining SuperCDMS-related outreach materials for SNOLAB in Canada and SURF. Existing alliances will enable out-reach to Sudbury First Nations communities. This effort will also support post-graduate education and outreach to underrepresented groups.

In order to maximize the science output of SuperCDMS SNOLAB, detailed understanding of the response of detectors to potential signals and backgrounds is required. Measurements at two underground facilities (NEXUS at Fermilab and CUTE at SNOLAB) will characterize and calibrate pre-production SuperCDMS SNOLAB detectors and the first production SuperCDMS SNOLAB towers, with supporting measurements from small devices at university test facilities. Resulting data will allow energy scale calibration, measurements of background levels, understanding of the detailed phonon and electron physics of the detectors, development of improved background-rejection techniques, validation and tuning of Detector Monte Carlo, and optimization of SuperCDMS SNOLAB operational parameters. These data should also provide a dark matter search with world-leading sensitivity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) are one of the main candidates to explain the mysterious dark matter in the universe, through new particle physics at the “TeV scale” or a “dark sector” which could co-exist with the ordinary matter that we know. A number of experiments are attempting to detect the WIMPs from the halo of our galaxy through their scattering in sophisticated detectors located deep underground. Over the last 30 years, the National Science Foundation and the Department of Energy have supported several experiments to check this hypothesis. The Cryogenic Dark Matter Search (CDMS) series of experiments uses sophisticated low temperature detectors operating underground to detect interactions of these putative WIMPs and distinguish them from experimental background. This work is based on a combination of advanced photolithographic techniques, state-of-the-art superconducting and semi-conductor electronics, and low radioactivity techniques. Because of its energy sensitivity and excellent background rejection capability, the CDMS approach is well adapted to search for dark matter particles of low mass which would deposit a very small amount of energy in their interactions with the nuclei or electrons of a target. And, it is complementary to the large liquid Xenon and Argon experiments, which explore the large WIMP masses.

After a very successful series of experiments based in the Soudan mine in Northern Minnesota, our collaboration is installing a new setup in the deeper SNOLAB underground laboratory in Sudbury (Ontario, Canada), with much improved radioactivity background and a more advanced set of detectors. This should allow us to explore, with world leading sensitivity, the low mass region (1/2 to 10 times the mass of the proton).

This SuperCDMS SNOLAB Experiment award—collaboratively with the other NSF-supported CDMS groups (University of Colorado at Denver, University of Florida, Northwestern University, and Southern Methodist University) —has allowed the University of California at Berkeley scientists (Prof. Bernard Sadoulet and Prof. Matt Pyle, and their postdoc and students) to continue their strong contributions to detector design and characterization and to mitigation efforts of parasitic phenomena for this new phase of the CDMS experiment. It has also enabled longer term detector R&D and has supported new science through the continued analysis of the SuperCDMS Soudan experiment, as well as the demonstration of the promising sensitivity of small more advanced dark matter detectors.  

These new techniques will undoubtedly have broad applications not only in SuperCDMS SNOLAB and the DOE supported Tesseract experiment exploring even lower WIMP masses, but also in other fields such as neutrinoless double beta decay and detection of coherent neutrino scattering. 

These efforts have led to 29 papers in the period of performance with 747 citations so far. The continued analysis of SuperCDMS Soudan has led to two main results: Our Constraints on dark photons and axionlike particles from the SuperCDMS Soudan experiment has received 51 citations. We also improved our results with voltage assisted ionization collection (CDMSLite) in a paper which received 110 citations. Berkeley also played a central role in the demonstration of single charge sensitivity on a small R&D device and in the analysis which led to world leading dark matter limits at very low WIMP mass (2018 Physical Review Letters with 234 citations and a follow up paper in Phys. Rev D with 104 citations). Our Light Dark Matter Search with a High-Resolution Athermal Phonon Detector Operated Above Ground (an 11g detector with 3.9 eV rms baseline resolution) received 71 citations.

This award has provided the data needed to support the PhD for two graduate students. Thirteen undergraduate students have also been directly involved. We are also actively engaged in an innovative education and outreach program, both collaboration wide and at Berkeley. Most notably, since 2004, Berkeley CDMS has supported the Summer Math and Science Honors (SMASH) Academy at UC Berkeley. This program offers a residential summer academy to promising high school students of color from underserved communities in the Bay Area. The Berkeley CDMS group organizes a very successful course on “Topics in Current Science Research” typically involving 40 rising 10th graders and 15 graduate student or postdoc mentors recruited from a broad range of UC Berkeley departments. In the last 3 years, the course has had to adapt to an online format to comply with COVID-19 restrictions. But this shift allowed us to introduce our 10th graders in 2020 and 2021 to the science behind the pandemic and to engage with a larger cohort of students.

Until March 2019, Berkeley CDMS Education & Outreach Specialist R. Winheld was the director of Science at Cal, an initiative to convey the diversity and richness of Berkeley’s science to the local community. In the same period, B. Sadoulet was the Faculty Lead of this campus-wide effort. Science at Cal has now been established as an autonomous outreach program at the Lawrence Hall of Science, with new funding and new personnel.
